The case is linked to an adult monkeypox infection that w...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) — Oregon health officials said Wednesday that the state has identified its first pediatric case of the monkeypox virus. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The case is linked to an adult monkeypox infection that was diagnosed in July, the Oregon Health Authority said in a statement.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Health authorities did not release any information about the patient, citing privacy. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Oregon has identified 116 presumed and confirmed cases of the monkeypox virus, including 112 men and four women, in seven counties. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The cases are located in the following counties: four in Clackamas, one in Columbia, one in Coos, 20 in Lane, one in Marion, 73 in Multnomah and 16 in Washington. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Nearly 12,700 cases have been diagnosed nationwide in 49 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Centers for Disease Control confirmed the first U.S. case of the disease on May 17. The World Health Organization declared the global spread of monkeypox to be an international emergency in July and the U.S. declared its own epidemic to be a national emergency earlier this month.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"Monkeypox","name":"Monkeypox","canonicalName":"monkeypox","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-science","name":"Science","canonicalName":"science","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"Oregon","name":"Oregon","canonicalName":"oregon","isPr":false},{"id":"Portland","name":"Portland","canonicalName":"portland","isPr":false},{"id":"DistrictofColumbia","name":"District (AP) — Doctors and other staffers at Boston Children’s Hospital are being threatened with violence over its surgical program for transgender youths, administrators said, and other U.S. child...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>BOSTON (AP) — Doctors and other staffers at Boston Children’s Hospital are being threatened with violence over its surgical program for transgender youths, administrators said, and other U.S. children’s hospitals are also being harassed online.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Boston Children’s is home to the first pediatric and adolescent transgender health program in the United States. It became the focus of far-right social media accounts, news outlets and bloggers last week after they found informational YouTube videos published by the hospital weeks ago about surgical offerings for transgender patients. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The hospital swiftly removed the videos. It said in a statement Tuesday that it is working with law enforcement to protect its staff and patients and to “hold the offenders accountable,” adding that it rejects the “false narrative” spreading online. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Some of the same social media accounts are now shifting their attention — and that of their millions of followers — to similar gender care programs at children’s hospitals in Pittsburgh and Phoenix. Those hospitals did not immediately respond to email and phone messages seeking comment. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/science-health-mental-ce8f5a9ee53768af03c3c65d5331045b\">Transition treatment\u003c/a> is under attack in many states, with some labeling it a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/texas-child-abuse-child-welfare-greg-abbott-ken-paxton-65c054b6ccd9040e81ad1a4be11403b9\">form of child abuse\u003c/a> or \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/health-florida-medicaid-government-and-politics-48527546590cb22ef19d10401fb0db05\">barring Medicaid coverage.\u003c/a> Critics argue that safety should be well established before subjecting youths to potentially irreversible treatments. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:921111348038' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='7a6bed81a86fe5576ca0145d893ad153'>Hub peek embed (apf-Health) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>But many medical groups support allowing varying types of medical treatment for transgender youths, citing evidence that it can improve their well-being, although rigorous long-term research on benefits and risks is lacking.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Republican candidates have also been \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/sports-texas-pennsylvania-campaigns-elections-5bb0f7fb8c162d9f4da5c935271bc255\">disparaging transgender people\u003c/a> in midterm election campaigns in a strategy designed to motivate the conservative base and sway swing voters, political observers say.\u003c/p>\u003cp>C.P. Hoffman, senior policy counsel at the National Center for Transgender Equality, said this is the first time they've heard of intense, targeted online attacks on children’s hospitals, though other organizations that provide services to trans people have faced significant harassment. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“It really makes one worry about the safety of trans youth and their families and the individuals who provide services to them,\" they said.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The Massachusetts Transgender Political Coalition also condemned the attacks as baseless claims continuing an assault on trans youth and trans health care that is spreading across the U.S.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Attacking children and those who care for them for seeking appropriate medical care is an indefensible position and at its core, an ill-fated attempt to erase transgender people from public life,” the coalition said in a statement.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The critics cited the videos and snippets of previous language on the hospital's website to claim that Boston Children’s Hospital was improperly performing gender-affirming surgeries, such as hysterectomies, on minors and “young” children. The response was swift and relentless, with a barrage of users demanding the hospital be shut down and calling the surgeries “mutilation,” “barbarism” and “child abuse,” while accusing its doctors of engaging in malpractice or illegal activity.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The hospital said it has received “a large volume” of hostile online messages, phone calls and harassing emails, including the threats of violence.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We are deeply concerned by these attacks on our clinicians and staff fueled by misinformation and a lack of understanding and respect for our transgender community,” the hospital said in its statement. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The hospital has updated language across its websites to emphasize that to qualify for most gender-affirming surgical procedures, patients must be at least 18 and meet certain criteria, including undergoing intensive medical and mental health evaluations and submitting letters of support.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Some of the online critics pointed to information that once appeared on the hospital's website that said to qualify for vaginoplasty at Boston Children’s, one must be at least 17 and meet certain criteria, as well as language for chest reconstruction and breast augmentation that remains on the website that says patients must be at least 15 and meet certain criteria. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Vaginoplasty is the creation of a vagina from existing genital tissue. A gender-affirming hysterectomy is the removal of the uterus and fallopian tubes, which can precede a phalloplasty, the surgical creation of a penis.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The hospital said it does not perform genital surgeries as part of gender-affirming care on a patient under age 18. It said that for surgical consultation, a patient must be 17 years old and 18 to 35 years old at the time of surgery. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The World Professional Association for Transgender Health, a global group that sets standards for medical care of trans youths and adults, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/gender-transition-treatment-guidelines-9dbe54f670a3a0f5f2831c2bf14f9bbb\">recently lowered its recommended minimum age\u003c/a> for starting gender transition treatment, including sex hormones and surgeries. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The new standards support starting hormones at age 14, two years earlier than before, and some surgeries at age 15 or 17, a year or so earlier than previous guidance. The group acknowledged potential risks but said it is unethical and harmful to withhold early treatment.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The Endocrine Society generally recommends starting those treatments a year or two later but is also updating its guidance. The American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Medical Association and the American Psychiatric Association are among other groups that support allowing medical treatment for transgender youths but don’t offer age-specific guidance.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-business","name":"Business","canonicalName":"business","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-lifestyle","name":"Lifestyle","canonicalName":"lifestyle","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-usnews","name":"U.S. ...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) — The head of the World Health Organization described the ongoing crisis in Ethiopia’s Tigray region as “the worst disaster on Earth” and wondered aloud Wednesday if the reason global leaders have not responded was due to “the color of the skin of the people in Tigray.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>In an emotional statement at a press briefing, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus — himself an ethnic Tigrayan — said the situation caused by the conflict in his home country is worse than any other humanitarian crisis in the world. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Tedros asserted that the 6 million people in Tigray essentially cut off from the world have been “under siege” for the last 21 months. He described the Ukraine conflict as a crisis that has the global community potentially “sleepwalking into a nuclear war\" that could be “the mother of all problems,” but argued the disaster in Tigray was far worse.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“I haven’t heard in the last few months any head of state talking about the Tigray situation anywhere in the developed world. Anywhere. Why?” Tedros asked. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“Maybe the reason is the color of the skin of the people in Tigray.” he said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>In \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-health-europe-ethiopia-world-health-organization-ac05cc5d4d9e459164cdfbeba6854f77\">April\u003c/a>, Tedros questioned if the world's overwhelming focus on Russia's war in Ukraine was due to racism, although he acknowledged the conflict there had global consequences. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:866061271240' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='09bce36f33719f793eaa79e1de520ad4'>Hub peek embed (Russia-Ukraine) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>The conflict in Ethiopia began in November 2020, and little humanitarian aid arrived after Tigray forces retook much of the region in June 2021. Aid has started flowing more substantially in the past few months but is widely described as inadequate to meet the needs of the millions of people essentially trapped there. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The resumption of basic services and banking remains a key demand of the Tigray regional leaders. Journalists have not been allowed in.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Tedros said the people of Tigray had no access to medicine and telecommunications and were prevented from leaving the region. However, the International Committee of the Red Cross in recent months has reported shipments of some medications. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“Nowhere in the world you would see this level of cruelty, where it’s a government (that) punishes 6 million of its people for more than 21 months,” the WHO chief said. “The only thing we ask is, ‘Can the world come back to its senses and uphold humanity?’” \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Tedros called on both the Ethiopian and Russian governments to end the crises in Tigray and Ukraine.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“If they want peace, they can make it happen and I urge them both to resolve (these issues),” he said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Also Wednesday, Ethiopia's foreign ministry said a government peace committee had adopted a peace proposal “that would lead to the conclusion of ceasefire” and that it would be shared with the African Union envoy working on mediation. Basic services would follow a ceasefire, the statement said. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Tigray forces spokesman Getachew Reda dismissed the government statement, asserting in a tweet that “if anything, the Abiy Ahmed regime has made it abundantly clear that it has no appetite for peaceful negotiations except as delaying tactics.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>In a sign of just how cut off Tigray has been, a COVID-19 vaccination campaign was finally launched at the region’s flagship hospital only in July, an improvement from a months-long period of deprivation in which hospital workers described running out of essential medicines and trying to treat wounds with warm salt water. It was the first COVID-19 vaccination campaign in Tigray.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>This was not the first time the WHO chief has spoken out about Tigray. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Earlier this year, the government of Ethiopia \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-health-africa-united-nations-ethiopia-02a7f67770e874d0b4747fb86882ecff\">sent a letter\u003c/a> to the World Health Organization, accusing Tedros of “misconduct” after his sharp criticism of the war and humanitarian crisis in the country.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Ethiopian government said Tedros was using his office “to advance his political interest at the expense of Ethiopia” and said he continues to be an active member of the Tigray People’s Liberation Front; Tedros was Ethiopia’s foreign minister and health minister when the TPLF dominated the country’s ruling coalition.\u003c/p>\u003cp>When Tedros was confirmed for a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/covid-health-united-nations-pandemics-a907db5588a485068dccde4ea86a5459\">second term\u003c/a> as head of WHO, it was the first time a candidate's home country had failed to nominate their own candidate. \u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Cheng reported from London. quarterback...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>CINCINNATI (AP) — Joe Burrow is trying to pack on the pounds, gaining back the weight he lost after having surgery to remove his ruptured appendix three weeks ago.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Cincinnati Bengals quarterback won't say how much he lost, but the pounds are coming back, along with the strength and mobility he had before the July 26 procedure.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The goal is for Burrow to be healthy for the regular-season opener against AFC North rival Pittsburgh in 3 1/2 weeks.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“I’m getting exponentially better each day,” Burrow said Wednesday in his first availability with reporters since the surgery. “Each day that I’m in the weight room, each day that I’m on the field I’m feeling stronger and stronger, so by Game 1 I’ll be feeling great.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Burrow began participating in training camp on Sunday, threw passes in 7-on-7 drills and was set to work in 11-on-11 drills on Wednesday. Of course, defensive players will have to keep their hands off the valuable quarterback. The Bengals want to keep him off the ground as long as possible.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“The more I’ve done each day, the better I felt the next day. That’s kind of how it’s always gone to me,” he said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Just getting my abs and my core re-engaged. When they cut into you and do all that stuff, your core is going to lose some muscle and strength. Just working to get that back.\"\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:466044750319' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='59f0a35fbc076942700ab388bc5b3154'>Hub peek embed (NFL) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>Don't expect to see Burrow play in the two remaining preseason games. Too big a risk. In fact, few if any Bengals starters are expected to play in the next one, against the New York Giants on Sunday.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Obviously, I would have liked to,” Burrow said. “This whole thing has kind of thrown a wrench into that. I don’t anticipate playing in a preseason game, though.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Coach Zac Taylor said the remaining preseason practices will be designed to get Burrow ready to go Sept. 11.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Trust me, we’ve dialed out every practice, and he and I have had conversations about how many opportunities we have left to make sure we check all the boxes before we go into Week 1,” Taylor said. “And we feel very confident that we’ll be able to do that and be prepared going into that game.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Before \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/cincinnati-bengals-zac-taylor-joe-burrow-nfl-sports-144e11281632024dfb61be27cc2cdcef\">the appendicitis\u003c/a>, the 25-year-old Burrow, who led the Bengals to the Super Bowl for the first time in 33 years in 2021, was enjoying a healthy, productive offseason after spending all of last year's training camp rehabbing from major knee surgery.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“I just think my whole career has been coming back from speed bumps and adversity,” he said. “I don’t know anything else. It’s another speed bump in the way.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Also Wednesday, Sports Illustrated introduced its NFL preview issue with Burrow \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SInow/status/1559889967148589056/photo/1\">on the cover.\u003c/a> The caption says “their ultracool QB has transformed the Bengals' vibe.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>Burrow shrugged it off.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\"It’s just something that comes with success that will go away without success,\" he said. “It doesn’t mean anything to me.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/NFL and Logan P...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) — An Oklahoma lawmaker has filed an Open Records Act lawsuit seeking records about expenditures from Governor’s Emergency Education Relief, or GEER, funds.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Republican Rep. Logan Phillips filed the lawsuit Tuesday against the Office of Management and Enterprise Services and said Gov. Kevin Stitt and Education Secretary Ryan Walters, also both Republicans, have not responded to his requests for the documents.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\"I am seeking declarative and injunctive relief because I believe failure to provide the requested records is unlawful and the records need to be made publicly available,” Phillips said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Stitt and OMES representatives told the Tulsa World that Phillips failed to attend scheduled meetings to see the documents.\u003c/p>\u003cp>A U.S. Department of Education \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/9a2edcdcf1805d05b3e0d0284a9f84d2\">audit in July\u003c/a> sharply criticized state officials for lack of oversight and accountability in how they used nearly $40 million in coronavirus relief funds intended for education. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The audit recommended the state return nearly $653,000 spent on non-educational items such as televisions and Xbox gaming systems and audit another $5.4 million for possible refund of misspent funds.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The state blamed the Florida-based contractor hired to administer the programs and sued the company for how it distributed (AP) — Attorneys for Florida school shooter Nikolas Cruz reversed course Wednesday and said they will not present at his ongoing penalty trial results of a highly contentious ...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) — Attorneys for Florida school shooter \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/hub/nikolas-cruz\">Nikolas Cruz\u003c/a> reversed course Wednesday and said they will not present at his ongoing penalty trial results of a highly contentious brain exam they had said supports their contention the mass murderer suffers from fetal alcohol syndrome. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Cruz attorney Casey Secor told Circuit Judge Elizabeth Scherer that they will not show jurors the controversial “quantitative electroencephalogram” or qEEG tests Cruz was given last year. The exam's backers say it provides useful support to such diagnoses as fetal alcohol syndrome, which Cruz’s attorneys contend helped create his lifelong mental and emotional problems. Prosecutors and critics say the test is unproven or even junk. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“We are not relying on those types of scans and comparisons,” Secor told the judge. He did not explain the decision.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Cruz's attorneys say fetal alcohol syndrome is one factor that led to his Feb. 14, 2018, attack at Parkland's Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School that left \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/education-florida-gun-politics-school-boards-nikolas-cruz-44a0da3e406f0c487e5c0a6b0855ee2e\">14 students and three staff members\u003c/a> dead. The sides had been poised to argue about the qEEG results before Scherer this week without the jury present in advance of the defense beginning its case Monday with his attorneys' \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/nikolas-cruz-parkland-shooting-trial-e8a15846f345b12e320e3f7b723086ff\">opening statement. \u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:921111348038' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='aeb06be78d30f3f95b5d735eab7e13b6'>Hub peek embed (apf-Health) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Cruz, 23, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/parkland-school-shooting-nikolas-cruz-guilty-plea-1bad323e22fe4517cf851395b252bd4b\">pleaded guilty in October\u003c/a> to 17 counts of first-degree murder — the trial is only to decide whether the former Stoneman Douglas student is sentenced to death or life without parole. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The qEEG exam is an extension of electroencephalogram or EEGs, which have been common in medicine for a century. Brainwaves are measured to help doctors diagnose epilepsy and other brain ailments. \u003c/p>\u003cp>But the qEEG analysis, which has been around since the 1970s, goes a step further — a patient’s EEG results are compared to a database of brainwaves taken from normal or “neurotypical” people. Although qEEG findings cannot be used to make a diagnosis, they can support findings based on the patient’s history, examination, behavior and other tests, supporters contend.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Cruz's prosecutors and other critics say the tests have never been proven to be valid and two exams on the same person can have widely different results. That's what happened with Cruz. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The defense will still have evidence about Cruz's troubled life and emotional and mental problems that they can present to the \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/florida-fort-lauderdale-parkland-school-shooting-nikolas-cruz-c06074b088078b31c46324b556b8f2f0\">seven-man, five-woman jury\u003c/a> and 10 alternates. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Lead defense attorney Melisa McNeill and her team will try to persuade at least one juror that the mitigating circumstances of Cruz's life outweigh the aggravating factors prosecutors presented during their case, which began July 18 and rested Aug. 4. A vote for death must be unanimous or else Cruz gets life. A juror also can vote for life out of mercy for Cruz. \u003c/p>\u003cp>They have statements by his late birth mother that she abused alcohol and cocaine during pregnancy. They also have reports giving circumstantial evidence of his mental illness. Cruz got kicked out of preschool for hurting other children. During his years in public school, he spent significant time at a center for students with emotional issues. He also received years of mental health treatment.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Then there are his life circumstances. Cruz’s adoptive father died in front of him when he was 5, he was bullied by his younger brother and his brother’s friends, he was allegedly abused sexually by a “trusted peer,” he cut himself and abused animals, and his adoptive mother died less than four months before the shooting.\u003c/p>\u003cp>His youth will also be an issue — he was 19 when the shooting happened.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The defense will be trying to overcome \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/health-crime-shootings-florida-fort-lauderdale-bdc8b0fdea8cf03ef6796b226aaf9673\">the horrendous evidence\u003c/a> that was laid out by the prosecution, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/nikolas-cruz-trial-parkland-shooting-scene-cf04bb9cebd45e01cf92db39e8c1a423\">capped by the jurors' Aug. 4 visit to the three-story building\u003c/a> that Cruz stalked with his \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/education-florida-fort-lauderdale-parkland-school-shooting-60791bdf38785f494400c43b90a97c39\">AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle\u003c/a> for seven minutes, firing about 150 shots down halls and into classrooms. The jurors saw dried blood on floors and walls, bullet holes in doors and windows and remnants of Valentine's Day balloons, flowers and cards. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Prosecutors also presented \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/crime-shootings-education-florida-fort-lauderdale-877f6c4a3e3ef6f5bf78ded33d619163\">graphic surveillance videos\u003c/a> of the massacre; \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/death-of-george-floyd-gun-violence-education-florida-fort-lauderdale-39c6ea954d24cbf6f15e39b826dff124\">gruesome crime scene and autopsy photos\u003c/a> from its aftermath; \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/shootings-education-florida-fort-lauderdale-b46046e051d58521d225c29d55d93565\">emotional testimony from teachers and students\u003c/a> who witnessed others die; and four days of \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/sports-shootings-education-florida-fort-lauderdale-bbb4f1f0317413afbe14a51e90fcdf17\">tearful and angry\u003c/a> statements from \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/education-florida-fort-lauderdale-parkland-school-shooting-nikolas-cruz-07073f4057a46630d09ccba695ff340a\">parents, spouses and other family members\u003c/a> about the victims and how their \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/entertainment-sports-education-movies-florida-9d87c439c291633716fe08246cd7b618\">loved one’s death affected their lives.\u003c/a> Jurors also watched video of Cruz calmly \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/shootings-education-florida-fort-lauderdale-parkland-school-shooting-c95f663e6262da40241fe354e4e363fd\">ordering an Icee minutes\u003c/a> after the shooting and, nine months later, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MtK-4oWK-QE&t=15s\">attacking a jail guard.\u003c/a>\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"Florida","name":"Florida","canonicalName":"florida","isPr":false},{"id":"FortLauderdale","name":"Fort (AP) — Planned Parenthood, the nation's leading reproductive health care provider and abortion rights advocacy organization, plans to spend a record $50 million ahead of November's midte...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>WASHINGTON (AP) — Planned Parenthood, the nation's leading reproductive health care provider and abortion rights advocacy organization, plans to spend a record $50 million ahead of \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/hub/2022-midterm-elections\">November's midterm elections\u003c/a>, pouring money into contests where access to abortion will be on the ballot. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The effort, which breaks the group's previous $45 million spending record set in 2020, comes about two months after \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/abortion-supreme-court-decision-854f60302f21c2c35129e58cf8d8a7b0\">the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade\u003c/a>, the landmark 1973 case that created a constitutional right to have an abortion. It will be waged by the organization's political and advocacy arms and will focus on governor's offices, U.S. Senate seats and legislative races in nine states where abortion rights could be restricted or expanded depending on the outcome at the ballot. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The historic proportions of the midterm campaign, when less money is usually spent, were made possible by \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/abortion-philanthropy-judiciary-f03d6df59a354544c764e00b700ae6ca\">a torrent of money raised after the decision by the high court's new conservative majority\u003c/a>, touching off a tectonic shift in the politics of abortion. Now, for the first time, Republicans who have long campaigned against abortion and Roe v. Wade will face voters on an issue that is no longer hypothetical and carries real life consequences. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:990851335744' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='71871318f3c725a7df0bbe183e6c84be'>Hub peek embed (2022Midtermelections) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Planned Parenthood says its spending will help remind voters in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Minnesota, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin what's at stake in a bid to drive turnout by Democratic and independent voters.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Who wins in these midterm elections will determine whether a state has access to abortion and potentially determine whether we will face a national abortion ban,” said Jenny Lawson, the executive director of Planned Parenthood Votes. “We will be clear about who is on which side.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/abortion-health-congress-government-and-politics-fc8c68d1c4dd29ef0a364050013b8cf4\">A recent poll by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research\u003c/a> found a majority of Americans think Congress should pass a law guaranteeing access to legal abortion nationwide. More than half of the respondents said they feel at least somewhat “sad” or “angry” about the Supreme Court’s decision.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Earlier this month in red-state Kansas, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/2022-primary-elections-kansas-abortion-b6d62a852c2ce4617f2c03589fbb523e\">voters rejected by nearly 20 percentage points\u003c/a> a constitutional amendment that would have allowed the legislature to advance a ban on abortion.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Whether it truly is a galvanizing issue will become clear after Election Day, Nov. 8. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“We say this every cycle: ‘This is the important election,'” said Amy Kennedy, a spokesperson for Planned Parenthood Votes in Georgia. “For us, this really is the most important election cycle of our life.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Planned Parenthood says it intends to contact 6 million voters through door knocking, phone calls, digital advertising, mailers and radio ads. It has already run some TV ads in Wisconsin, where Republicans control the statehouse and where Democratic Gov. Tony Evers and Republican U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson are up for reelection. \u003c/p>\u003cp>It also is launching a website, \u003ca href=\"https://www.takecontrol2022.com/\">takecontrol2022.com\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\u003cp>While the Supreme Court's ruling in June effectively left setting abortion policy to the states, Planned Parenthood says it is also investing in U.S. Senate races because \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/abortion-health-mitch-mcconnell-government-and-politics-3cf10d1e1b3dc46ea202a466a86ae9ea\">Republicans have expressed an interest in pursuing a national abortion ban\u003c/a>, though such a measure would almost certainly be vetoed by President Joe Biden.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Democrats and their allies have long tried, without much success, to energize supporters by focusing on abortion. But the Supreme Court’s decision clarified the stakes as never before. In roughly a dozen states led by Republicans, abortion has already been banned or heavily restricted. Many more are expected to follow.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“When people go to vote this November, nearly half of the folks voting could be living in a state that either has already banned abortion or is quickly moving to ban abortion. These are entirely new circumstances,” Lawson said. “There are a lot of issues people care about, certainly, but the state of abortion access is absolutely one of the defining issues this November.\"\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Follow AP's coverage of the midterm elections at \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/hub/2022-midterm-elections\">https://apnews.com/hub/2022-midterm-elections\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"2022Midtermelections","name":"2022 (AP) — Gov. Mark Gordon has a clear path to reelection after winning the Republican primary in Wyoming on Tuesday, while state Rep. Chuck Gray won the GOP primary for secretary of st...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>CHEYENNE, Wyo. (AP) — Gov. Mark Gordon has a clear path to reelection after winning the Republican primary in Wyoming on Tuesday, while state Rep. Chuck Gray won the GOP primary for secretary of state. Megan Degenfelder defeated incumbent Brian Schroeder in the GOP primary for state superintendent of public instruction.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Democrats, meanwhile, have all but ceded these offices to Republicans, fielding just two candidates who don't even have websites for governor and just one candidate for state superintendent.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Here's a look at the races for Wyoming's five statewide elected officials:\u003c/p>\u003cp>GOVERNOR\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gordon had faced fierce opposition within the GOP for public health measures to limit the spread of the coronavirus, causing speculation he’d face a tough primary challenge. He didn’t, after lifting a statewide mask mandate and other coronavirus restrictions. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Last year, Gordon urged the National Rifle Association to move its headquarters from Virginia to Wyoming. In March, he signed a ban on most abortions that briefly took effect a month after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and is now on hold pending a lawsuit contesting the ban. Both moves helped buttress Gordon’s right-wing credentials.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:990851335744' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='ceda97151f2957d1de2f5a5c3300ac3c'>Hub peek embed (2022Midtermelections) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>And while Gordon hasn’t gone out of his way to praise Donald Trump, neither has he criticized the former president’s fixation on the false belief that fraud cost him reelection in 2020, which as \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/2022-midterm-elections-donald-trump-presidential-wyoming-alaska-48a5444f247727d26cf67a0a72f14637\">U.S. Rep. Liz Cheney discovered\u003c/a> may have courted a serious primary challenge.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gordon on Tuesday defeated Brent Bien, a retired U.S. Marine Corps colonel who oversaw operations in Guam. Bien, of Sheridan, campaigned in part on questioning Gordon’s coronavirus restrictions.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Also running Tuesday were Rex Rammell, of Rock Springs, a veterinarian and perennial, unsuccessful candidate for various offices in Idaho and Wyoming, and Douglas oilfield services business owner and Marine veteran James Scott Quick, who ran on protecting the state’s energy industry.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Retired U.S. Bureau of Land Management employee Theresa Livingston, of Worland, defeated retired cabinetmaker and perennial candidate Rex Wilde, of Cheyenne, in their race for the Democratic nomination for governor.\u003c/p>\u003cp>SECRETARY OF STATE\u003c/p>\u003cp>State Rep. Chuck Gray defeated Sen. Tara Nethercott in the GOP race to replace Wyoming Secretary of State Ed Buchanan, who is leaving his post after Gordon appointed him to become a state District Court judge.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>A former political radio commentator who’s the son of a Casper radio station owner, Gray has proven one of Wyoming’s most Trump-like legislators since his election to the state House in 2016.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gray ran briefly for U.S. House in 2021, railing against Cheney after she voted to impeach the former president for the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. He visited Arizona to see and be seen at a recount of the 2020 presidential vote in that state.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gray abandoned his congressional campaign after failing to get Trump’s endorsement. Trump did endorse his candidacy for secretary of state. \u003c/p>\u003cp>As Wyoming’s No. 2 state official, the secretary of state oversees elections and business licensing.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Nethercott is a Cheyenne attorney who has served in the state Senate since 2017 and chairs the chamber’s Judiciary Committee. Like Gray, she made “election integrity” a campaign focus. Nethercott also promised to keep state business administration fees low.\u003c/p>\u003cp>STATE SUPERINTENDENT\u003c/p>\u003cp>In a close race, Megan Degenfelder, a former chief policy officer in the education department, defeated incumbent Brian Schroeder in the GOP primary for state superintendent. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Degenfelder, from Laramie, served in the education department under Jillian Balow, who left Wyoming to lead Virginia’s public school system. In her campaign, Degenfelder called for doing “more with less” amid a tight state budget and prioritized funding for classrooms over administration.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Schroeder was appointed state superintendent in January by Gordon to replace Balow. A former head of a private Christian school in Cody, Schroeder ran for the job under the slogan “Wyoming Education - Not Indoctrination.” He promised to “refuse to let our kids become pawns of the social engineers who are hell-bent on grooming them into their relativistic value system.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Also running was Republican Jennifer Zerba, a Casper substitute teacher who called for more fiscal transparency in schools.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Educator and Northern Arapaho tribal elder Sergio Maldonado was the lone Democrat running for state superintendent. \u003c/p>\u003cp>STATE TREASURER\u003c/p>\u003cp>Incumbent Republican Curt Meier defeated Bill Gallop, a Cheyenne-based investment officer for the Wyoming Retirement System.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Meier, endorsed by Trump for a second term, is a former state legislator with a farm and ranch in the LaGrange area. Meier said the state treasurer’s office had beaten its investment benchmarks in his first term and that he'd helped to expand access to low-income housing.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gallop had criticized Wyoming’s state investments under Meier for lagging behind U.S. stock market returns, calling them on his website a “broken engine with seven of eight cylinders busted.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>STATE AUDITOR\u003c/p>\u003cp>Republican Auditor Kristi Racines, of Cheyenne, is unopposed for a second term.\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Anderson reported from Denver.\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Follow Mead Gruver at \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/meadgruver\">https://twitter.com/meadgruver\u003c/a>\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"2022Midtermelections","name":"2022 worse...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>NEW YORK (AP) — A small museum near New York's World Trade Center dedicated to preserving the memory of the Sept. 11 attacks is closing after Wednesday, the victim of financial pressures made worse by COVID-19.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://911tributemuseum.org/\">The 9/11 Tribute Museum,\u003c/a> which opened in 2006, offered tours led by volunteers who had lost a family member or were connected in some other way to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. It was sometimes confused with the much larger Sept. 11 museum, which opened in 2014 near the memorial pools that mark where the twin towers stood.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Financial hardship including lost revenue caused by the pandemic prevents us from generating sufficient funding to continue to operate the physical museum,” Jennifer Adams, co-founder and CEO of the 9/11 Tribute Museum, said in a statement. She said the Tribute Museum would maintain an online presence to provide educational resources and support for the 9/11 community.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Most of the museum’s collection of artifacts from the Sept. 11 attacks is being moved to the New York State Museum in Albany, Adams said. The nonprofit September 11th Families’ Association, which founded the Tribute Museum, is coordinating with its donors to make sure that the artifacts are handled property, she said.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"Coronaviruspandemic","name":"COVID-19","canonicalName":"coronavirus-pandemic","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-Travel","name":"Travel","canonicalName":"travel","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-lifestyle","name":"Lifestyle","canonicalName":"lifestyle","isPr":false},{"id":"NewYork","name":"New Both cases involved o...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) — A restaurant customer in Fort Lauderdale has died of a bacterial infection after eating raw oysters. A Pensacola man died the same way this month. Both cases involved oysters from Louisiana.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Gary Oreal, who manages the Rustic Inn, told the \u003ca href=\"https://www.sun-sentinel.com/health/fl-ne-florida-man-dies-from-eating-raw-oyster-20220816-ruaxpgl7mrcirpgbb3gljrbysq-story.html\">South Florida SunSentinel\u003c/a> that the man who died had worked years ago at the restaurant famous for garlic crabs.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Over the course of 60 years, we have served a couple billion oysters, and we never had anyone get sick like this guy did,” Oreal said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says Vibrio bacteria doesn’t make an oyster look, smell, or taste any different. The agency said about 80,000 people get vibriosis in the U.S. each year, and about 100 people die from it.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Inspectors from the Florida Department of Health checked out the restaurant's kitchen and examined its oyster inventory the day after the man became ill, Oreal told the newspaper.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“We passed with flying colors and we were allowed to continue to sell oysters,” he said, adding the oysters being served currently are from Louisiana. “If there was a problem with the oyster bed we would know it because others would have gotten sick.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>The restaurant has a sign warning patrons about the risks of eating raw shellfish.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:921111348038' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='df631469f352c7a0c0403ec3a3ef5c8e'>Hub peek embed (apf-Health) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>“Oysters are top of the mountain for dangerous foods to eat,” Oreal said. “I have eaten them my entire life, and will continue. But you are putting yourself at risk when you do it.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Florida Department of Health says 26 people have become infected with the bacteria and six of them later died after eating raw shellfish, including oysters, so far this year. In 2021, 10 people died out of 34 people sickened. In 2020, there were seven deaths among the 36 who became ill.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Last week, a man in Pensacola died after contracting the bacteria from oysters he bought at a market, the Pensacola News Journal \u003ca href=\"https://www.pnj.com/story/news/2022/08/11/pensacola-community-leader-rodney-jackson-died-vibrio-bacteria-oyster/10285366002/\">reported\u003c/a>. That oyster also came from Louisiana, officials said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Infections linked to the bacteria are common in oysters and raw seafood during the summer months when water temperatures are warmer, University of West Florida Professor Robert “Wes” Farr told the newspaper.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Serious infection is rare, but the risk is still there,” Farr said.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"Louisiana","name":"Louisiana","canonicalName":"louisiana","isPr":false},{"id":"Florida","name":"Florida","canonicalName":"florida","isPr":false},{"id":"FortLauderdale","name":"Fort Pakistan (AP) — Veterinarians from a global animal welfare organization are in Pakistan and on Wednesday began a series of surgeries on a pair of elephants at a zoo in the port city of Kar...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) — Veterinarians from a global animal welfare organization are in Pakistan and on Wednesday began a series of surgeries on a pair of elephants at a zoo in the port city of Karachi. \u003c/p>\u003cp>During a previous visit last year, vets from Four Paws examined four elephants in Karachi and determined that one of the animals needs a “complicated” surgery to remove a damaged and infected tusk. A second elephant has dental problems and a medical issue with a foot, the vets said at the time.\u003c/p>\u003cp>On Tuesday, an eight-member team from Four Paws arrived in Pakistan to treat the animals. The surgeries and medical treatment are expected to wrap up on Friday.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Amir Khalil, who heads the team of vets, veterinary surgeons and wildlife experts, said the other two elephants in Karachi — kept in a public park in the city — will also get medical treatment. He did not elaborate. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Four Paws also plans to offer instructions to Karachi zoo caretakers on ensuring better care of the elephants.\u003c/p>\u003cp>In 2020, an elephant named Kaavan was transferred from Islamabad to Cambodia and now lives in an elephant sanctuary. Kaavan had languished in the Islamabad zoo for 35 years, most of that time in chains, and he lost his partner in 2012.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-lifestyle","name":"Lifestyle","canonicalName":"lifestyle","isPr":false},{"id":"Pakistan","name":"Pakistan","canonicalName":"pakistan","isPr":false},{"id":"Animals","name":"Animals","canonicalName":"animals","isPr":false},{"id":"Elephants","name":"Elephants","canonicalName":"elephants","isPr":false},{"id":"Animalwelfare","name":"Animal Superior Court Judge Joe Burrowes ruled Tuesday th...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>RICHLAND, Wash. (AP) — The man accused of fatally shooting a man inside Richland’s Fred Meyer store was ordered to take mental health medications. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Superior Court Judge Joe Burrowes ruled Tuesday that Eastern State Hospital can require Aaron Kelly, 40, to take the anti-psychotic Abilify to treat an unspecified schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder, Tri-City Herald \u003ca href=\"https://www.tri-cityherald.com/news/local/crime/article264564856.html\">reported\u003c/a>. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The treatment is scheduled to last until late September when he will return to court to determine if he is competent to stand trial for murder and attempted murder.\u003c/p>\u003cp>If he has not improved, his treatment could be extended. Kelly objected to the ruling. He has refused any medications stronger than a multivitamin during his four months at the Medical Lake facility.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Kelly is accused of shooting two strangers on Feb. 7 — Instacart worker Justin Krumbah and Fred Meyer employee Mark Hill. Krumbah died in the store, and Hill was wounded three times but survived.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>He was charged with murder and attempted murder. Legal proceedings have been on hold since Feb. 23 when defense attorneys asked to have his competency evaluated. \u003c/p>\u003cp>After months of waiting, psychologist Brooke England returned with an opinion that Kelly wasn’t mentally healthy enough to stand trial. \u003c/p>\u003cp>As part of the diagnosis, she said the hospital would need to administer medication. It still remains unclear why he doesn’t want medication, he argued that he has participated in other therapy since a June order was entered to restore his competency. \u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-Health","name":"Health","canonicalName":"health","isPr":false},{"id":"Crime","name":"Crime","canonicalName":"crime","isPr":false},{"id":"Shootings","name":"Shootings","canonicalName":"shootings","isPr":false},{"id":"Medication","name":"Medication","canonicalName":"medication","isPr":false}],"textColor":null,"layoutType":null,"customLayoutType":null,"styleName":null,"endDateTime":null,"teamLimit":25,"medalCounts":null,"medalsUpdated":null,"olympicYear":null,"notificationUrl":null,"notificationText":null,"notificationTitle":null,"notificationType":null,"notificationUpdated":null,"adUnits":null,"displayPositionHome":null,"displayPositionApp":null,"featuredCard":null,"publishedDate":"2022-08-17 13:00:15"},{"id":"urn:publicid:ap.org:91abb234b563f70c4ad3960a61fdad5b","shortId":"urn:publicid:ap.org:91abb234b563f70c4ad3960a61fdad5b","allowAd":true,"borderColor":null,"brackets":null,"bracketsSettings":null,"cardTitle":null,"embedCardTitleColor":null,"cardHeadline":null,"cardType":"Wire Story","collectionTagObjs":null,"contents":[{"id":"urn:publicid:ap.org:91abb234b563f70c4ad3960a61fdad5b","shortId":"91abb234b563f70c4ad3960a61fdad5b","bylines":"By TERESA M. Fans are ...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[{"id":"se0:c1a83250-02f0-11ed-cb31-7d5e02392c85","html":"\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-partner=\"tweetdeck\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The NFL essentially is back to normal entering its third season amid COVID-19 with fans up close to their favorite players for autographs, high-fives and handshakes\u003cbr>\u003cbr>by \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TeresaMWalker?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@teresamwalker\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/EVLojl8NkV\">https://t.co/EVLojl8NkV\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/ZMJLDtW0pu\">pic.twitter.com/ZMJLDtW0pu\u003c/a>\u003c/p>— AP NFL (@AP_NFL) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AP_NFL/status/1559607023196688384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 16, 2022\u003c/a>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cscript async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\n ","caption":" \n ","display":"se0","maxWidth":"","alignment":"middle","isHeroImage":false}],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) — Derrick Henry has been seen jogging on the field with his daughter after practice. \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/sports-nfl-health-minnesota-vikings-green-bay-packers-3ee882049ba0e932fa3d1291c7773f88\">Green Bay Packers are once again borrowing kids' bicycles\u003c/a> for rides to practice. Fans are rubbing elbows with their favorite players to get those coveted autographs. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Yes, the \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/hub/nfl\">NFL\u003c/a> is looking and acting like it's essentially back to normal going into its third season dealing with COVID-19.\u003c/p>\u003cp>There are no more trailers or tents for testing, and masks are rare. In fact, the protocols devised and tweaked by the league and the NFL Players Association in 2020 and 2021 were \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-nfl-business-sports-health-62d42bf438a0dc394cfae434e6540dbc\">suspended last March. \u003c/a>\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"social-embed\" id=\"se0:c1a83250-02f0-11ed-cb31-7d5e02392c85\">\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-partner=\"tweetdeck\">\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The NFL essentially is back to normal entering its third season amid COVID-19 with fans up close to their favorite players for autographs, high-fives and handshakes\u003cbr>\u003cbr>by \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TeresaMWalker?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@teresamwalker\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/EVLojl8NkV\">https://t.co/EVLojl8NkV\u003c/a> \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/ZMJLDtW0pu\">pic.twitter.com/ZMJLDtW0pu\u003c/a>\u003c/p>— AP NFL (@AP_NFL) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/AP_NFL/status/1559607023196688384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 16, 2022\u003c/a>\u003c/blockquote>\n\u003cscript async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\">\u003c/script>\n \u003cp class=\"social-caption\"> \n \u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The NFL seems to be following the lead of the \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/covid-science-health-pandemics-public-ace8870b5e4ac4500aa06964db0544b8\">CDC, which dropped social distancing and quarantine requirements\u003c/a> last week with an estimated 95% of Americans 16 and older acquiring some level of immunity from vaccinations or infections.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The league still wants anyone with possible symptoms to speak up and wear a mask after contact with someone with COVID-19. A positive test still means isolating at home for at least five days. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>“I think we are always concerned about everybody’s safety, ours and the health of our families,” Tennessee Titans coach Mike Vrabel said, adding that 2 1/2 years into the pandemic: \"Hopefully we are past that.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>The biggest changes have been the easiest to notice at training camps across the NFL: Fans are back and close enough to high-five and shake hands with players, no longer kept at a distance and happy to resume preseason traditions.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Players are happy to have fans fully back, grateful for the energy boost during the monotonous routine and long days of camp. \u003c/p>\u003cp>\"It’s huge,\" Packers running back Aaron Jones said. “The fans are everything. They're what makes football go, and I would say this is one of the best traditions in football, the bike rides. I’ve had my same little bike rider since I came in, got to bring my son to practice with me as well, so it’s special to me.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Packers were among the teams that allowed fans to watch training camp practices in 2021 at a distance, though no interaction with players was allowed. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Cheers are very welcome after the relative silence the past two years when the only sounds were pads thudding, coaches yelling and occasionally music over speakers to simulate fan noise. Families of players, coaches and team staffers couldn't attend either, preventing them from stealing a few minutes at work with their kids or spouses. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Henry's daughter Valentina, now 2, is the perfect age to enjoy racing her father to an end zone after an early practice at camp. The two-time NFL rushing champ said it's the kind of moment his daughter can look at when older. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>“Having these moments are always precious, especially with your kids, but just being in football and training camp it takes up a lot of time,” Henry said. “But any time you get a moment like that, you always cherish those moments and something that we can look back at and laugh at and enjoy.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>Vaccinations eased the \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/sports-virus-outbreak-denver-broncos-football-nfl-f737415053af38b361557ed4e64292de\">protocols from 2020\u003c/a> when teammates had to keep 6 feet apart and coaches wore masks on the field whether in practice or games no matter if teams were inside or outdoors. Titans center Ben Jones said that meant friends sitting apart for breakfast and lunch, making it tough to build team chemistry and camaraderie. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“It made it a lot of challenges for me who’s a guy who’s trying to get five guys on the same page to do it spread out,” Ben Jones recalled. \"It’s not what you want. As a guy on the team, as a leader, you want as many guys as close as possible so you can have an impact on them.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>The social distancing signs are gone. So too are the mandatory tests, saving time each morning spent waiting for a positive or negative result. \u003c/p>\u003cp>No NFL regular-season games were canceled the past two seasons because of the pandemic, though many were moved around during 2020 with the entire preseason scrapped. About 95% of the players and nearly 100% of team personnel were vaccinated, the league reported.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Titans had the first outbreak of the 2020 season, and Vrabel tested positive during the 2021 preseason at the start of another outbreak for the team.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Other professional leagues also are adjusting protocols;\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>— Major League Baseball dropped regular COVID-19 testing for all but symptomatic individuals prior to the start of the 2022 season.\u003c/p>\u003cp>— The \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/PR_NHL/status/1559646387020746754\">NHL\u003c/a> and NHL Players Association released \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/NHLPA/status/1559643064486051843\">updated protocols\u003c/a> Tuesday afternoon “strongly” encouraging vaccinations and booster shots and testing only when symptoms are present. Much like the NBA and MLB, unvaccinated individuals won’t be able to cross the border between the U.S. and Canada. Unvaccinated players risk suspension and lost pay for missing “team activities,\" though the NHL only has a couple of players and assistant coaches in that category.\u003c/p>\u003cp>— The NBA hasn't revealed its full policy for the upcoming season. \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/boston-celtics-golden-state-warriors-nba-sports-san-francisco-c20e8233302339abc59526f5ba48d0f1\">Commissioner Adam Silver\u003c/a> said last month he’s expecting continued movement toward normalcy, “I have learned over the last 2 1/2 years not to make any predictions when it comes to COVID, but only to say we’ll be prepared for anything that comes our way.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>AP Pro Football Writer Josh Dubow, AP Basketball Writer Tim Reynolds, AP Hockey Writers Stephen Whyno and John Wawrow and AP Sports Writers Steve Megargee and Jake Seiner contributed to this report. \u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>More AP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/nfl and https://apnews.com/hub/pro-32 and Zimbabwe (AP) — A measles outbreak in Zimbabwe has killed 157 children, most of whom were unvaccinated due to their family's religious beliefs, officials said. The measles outbreak was firs...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) — A measles outbreak in Zimbabwe has killed 157 children, most of whom were unvaccinated due to their family's religious beliefs, officials said. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The measles outbreak was first reported in the eastern Manicaland province in early April and has since spread to all parts of the country. \u003c/p>\u003cp>At least 2,056 cases have been reported and virtually all of the deaths have been children who were not vaccinated, Information Minister Monica Mutsvangwa said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Zimbabwe's Cabinet has invoked a law used to respond to disasters to deal with the outbreak, she said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The government says it is embarking on a mass vaccination campaign targeting children aged between 6 months and 15 years old and is engaging traditional and faith leaders to support the drive. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Zimbabwe continued vaccinating children against measles even during the height of the coronavirus pandemic, but the drive has been hampered by religious groups that preach against vaccines. The Christian sects are against modern medicine and tell their members to rely on self-proclaimed prophets for healing. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Church gatherings that have resumed following the easing of COVID-19 restrictions have “led to the spread of measles to previously unaffected areas,” said the health ministry in a statement last week. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:209878217955' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='3bc04c00ef567511075ed8d6af799d16'>Hub peek embed (Coronaviruspandemic) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>Measles is among the most infectious diseases in the world and mostly spreads in the air by coughing, sneezing or close contact. Symptoms include coughing, fever and a skin rash, while the risk of severe measles or dying from complications is high among unvaccinated children. Outbreaks in unvaccinated and malnourished populations have been known to kill thousands. Scientists estimate that more than 90% of the population needs to be immunized to prevent measles outbreaks.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The World Health Organization in April warned of an increase in measles in vulnerable countries as a result of a disruption of services due to COVID-19. In July, UNICEF said about 25 million children worldwide have missed out on routine immunizations against common childhood diseases, calling it a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/covid-health-united-nations-immunizations-childhood-3d5c0cdb95706412a249645d60c66a34\">“red alert”\u003c/a> for child health. United Arab Emirates (AP) — Dubai International Airport saw a surge in passengers over the first half of 2022 as pandemic restrictions eased and the upcoming FIFA World Cup in Qatar will fur...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) — Dubai International Airport saw a surge in passengers over the first half of 2022 as pandemic restrictions eased and the upcoming FIFA World Cup in Qatar will further boost traffic to the city-state’s second airfield, its chief executive said Wednesday.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Paul Griffiths, who oversees the world’s busiest airport for international travel, told The Associated Press that the airport handled 160% more traffic over the past six months compared to the same period last year, part of an air travel rebound around the world.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The nearly 28 million people who traveled through the airport over the past six months represent some 70% of the airport’s pre-pandemic levels, even as Dubai’s key source market of China remains closed due to severe pandemic restrictions. Griffiths said he expects the airport's traffic to return to pre-pandemic levels by the end of next year.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“It’s a very, very welcome surge of traffic,” Griffiths said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The first World Cup in the Middle East, he added, will send foreign soccer fans flocking to Al Maktoum International Airport at Dubai World Central, or DWC. From there, they'll travel daily to Qatar, a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/soccer-sports-travel-lifestyle-business-bc27c4b365dc57a85fd08859090185ef\">tiny neighbor that faces a hotel squeeze\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We've actually seen a huge amounts of demand at DWC for slot filings for airlines wanting to operate a shuttle service,\" he said. “I think the city has a lot to offer and a lot to gain from the World Cup.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:866061271240' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='eb36dd9e35b4b9e29799d58e727a5dc6'>Hub peek embed (Russia-Ukraine) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>Among the airlines buying extra slots to shuttle soccer fans to the tournament from DWC are Qatar Airways, low-cost carrier FlyDubai and budget airline Wizz Air Abu Dhabi, he said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/61860bce650842658a8bff6ec40a7d22\">Ambitions plans\u003c/a> to turn the airfield in Dubai's southern desert into a mega-aviation hub, first unveiled by Dubai before the 2008 global financial crisis, have sputtered in recent years. Long-haul carrier Emirates, based in Dubai, parked many of its double-decker Airbus A380s there during the pandemic as commercial flights halted.\u003c/p>\u003cp>A key East-West transit point, Dubai's air traffic is closely watched as a barometer of the city-state's non-oil economy. Emirates \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-financial-markets-ap-top-news-global-trade-united-arab-emirates-7b87b841e66ab324e029b0ba7f899ee6\">remains the linchpin of the wider empire\u003c/a> known as “Dubai Inc.,” an interlocking series of government-owned businesses.\u003c/p>\u003cp>During the first half of 2022, Dubai International Airport dealt with nearly 56% more flights than the same period in 2021, when contagious coronavirus variants clobbered the industry.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Now, in a sign of the health of the industry, Emirates said Wednesday that it would pour billions of dollars into retrofitting much of its Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 fleet. At the height of the pandemic, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/53121d88c71dee5858b42b88faf309c0\">the airline received a $4 billion government bailout\u003c/a>. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The widespread lifting of virus restrictions has triggered a rapid increase in air travel demand, filling Dubai’s hub and causing mayhem at airports around the world.\u003c/p>\u003cp>While Dubai has not seen the chaotic crowds overwhelming European hubs in recent weeks, Griffiths said the global disruptions have affected its main airport.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“It’s obviously affected growth because some of the caps on capacity that they’ve applied to airports like Heathrow have had an impact on our numbers,” he said. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Last month Emirates lashed out at Heathrow, refusing its request to cap departing passengers and cut flights to the London hub. Emirates later agreed to temporarily limit sales on its flights.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Since Moscow's invasion of Ukraine sent Russia’s richest businessmen scrambling to save their assets from what became a widening dragnet, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-politics-technology-middle-east-c6592eb5a483c7d95e47cc9bd8f77bde\">Dubai has welcomed an influx of Russians\u003c/a> to its beach-front villas and luxury hotels. The city remains one of the few remaining flight corridors out of Moscow. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Griffiths declined to comment on Russians carrying cash out of the country to Dubai, which has become the talk of the town in recent months. \u003c/p>\u003cp>But he said the flow of Russian visitors would not stop anytime soon, adding: “It's still a major source of traffic for us.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Follow Isabel DeBre on Twitter at www.twitter.com/isabeldebre.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"Russia-Ukraine","name":"Russia-Ukraine South Korea (AP) — South Korea’s president said Wednesday his government has no plans to pursue its own nuclear deterrent and called instead for more diplomacy in the face of growing North K...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — South Korea’s president said Wednesday his government has no plans to pursue its own nuclear deterrent and called instead for more diplomacy in the face of growing North Korean nuclear weapons capabilities, even as the North test-fired two suspected cruise missiles.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The launches were detected from North Korea’s western coast hours before South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol used a news conference to urge Pyongyang to return to diplomacy aimed at exchanging denuclearization steps for economic benefits.\u003c/p>\u003cp>South Korea’s military, which didn’t reveal the launches until after Yoon’s remarks, provided no immediate flight details about the North’s weapons, including how they moved or how far they traveled.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon’s office said his national security director, Kim Sung-han, discussed the launch with other senior officials before Yoon addressed reporters and that they reviewed the South’s military readiness. Tensions could further rise as the United States and South Korea kick off their biggest combined training in years next week to counter the North Korean threat. The North describes such drills as invasion rehearsals and has often responded to them with missile tests or other provocations.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:209878217955' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='03a5e316e02f8363f3d25dce818238e3'>Hub peek embed (Coronaviruspandemic) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Yoon during the news conference maintained a reserved tone on Pyongyang, saying Seoul doesn’t desire political change in North Korea that’s brought by force and that the rivals should aim at building sustainable peace.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon’s comments followed his proposal on Monday for an “audacious” economic assistance package to North Korea if it abandons its nuclear weapons program. He has avoided harsh criticism of the North after it threatened “deadly” retaliation last week over a COVID-19 outbreak it blames on the South.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon’s proposal for large-scale aid in food and healthcare and modernizing power and port infrastructure resembled previous South Korean offers that were rejected by North Korea, which is speeding its development of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, seen by leader Kim Jong Un as his strongest guarantee of survival. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Still, Yoon expressed hope for “meaningful dialogue” with North Korea over his plan and stressed that Seoul is willing to provide corresponding economic rewards at each step of a phased denuclearization process if the North commits to a genuine “roadmap” toward fully abandoning its weapons program.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“We are not telling them to ‘denuclearize entirely first and then we will provide,’” Yoon said. “What we are saying is that we will provide the things we can in correspondence to their steps if they only show a firm determination (toward denuclearization).”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Inter-Korean ties have worsened amid a stalemate in larger nuclear negotiations between North Korea and the U.S. that derailed in early 2019 because of disagreements over a relaxation of crippling U.S.-led sanctions on the North in exchange for disarmament steps. \u003c/p>\u003cp>North Korea has ramped up its missile testing to a record pace in 2022, launching more than 30 ballistic weapons so far, including its first intercontinental ballistic missiles in nearly five years. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The heighted testing activity underscores North Korea’s dual intent to advance its arsenal and force the United States to accept the idea of the North as a nuclear power so it can negotiate economic and security concessions from a position of strength, experts say. Kim could up the ante soon as there are indications that the North is preparing to conduct its first nuclear test since September 2017, when it claimed to have developed a thermonuclear weapon to fit on its ICBMs.\u003c/p>\u003cp>While Kim’s ICBMs get much of the international attention, North Korea is also expanding its range of nuclear-capable, short-range missiles that can target South Korea. Kim has punctuated his weapons development with threats to proactively use his nuclear weapons in conflicts against the South or the U.S., which experts say communicate an escalating nuclear doctrine that could increase concerns for its neighbors.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon has vowed to strengthen the South’s defenses through its alliance with the United States by resuming large-scale military training that was canceled or downsized during the Trump years and boosting the South’s missile defenses. The Biden administration has also reaffirmed U.S. commitments to defending South Korea and Japan, including “extended deterrence,” referring to an assurance to defend its allies with its full military capabilities, including nuclear.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>But some experts say it’s becoming clear South Korea has no clear way to counter the leverage North Korea has with its nukes, expressing concerns that Washington might hesitate to defend its ally in the event of war when Kim’s ICBMs would pose a potential threat to mainland American cities.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Some South Koreans have called for the reintroduction of tactical U.S. nuclear weapons that were removed from the South in the 1990s, or for Seoul to pursue its own deterrent. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon dismissed the possibility of the latter during the news conference, saying that Seoul will stay committed to an international treaty aimed at preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“I believe the NPT (Non-Proliferation Treaty) regime is a very important and necessary premise for permanent world peace,” Yoon said, expressing hope that the U.S. deterrence strategy for its allies could evolve to counter the North’s growing threat.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Yoon’s comments came after North Korea last week claimed a widely disputed victory over COVID-19 but also blamed South Korea for the outbreak. North Korea insists leaflets and other objects flown across the border by activists spread the virus, an unscientific claim Seoul describes as “ridiculous.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>North Korea has a history of dialing up pressure on South Korea when it doesn’t get what it wants from the United States, and there are concerns that North Korea’s threat portends a provocation, which could include a nuclear or missile test or even border skirmishes. Some experts say North Korea may stir up tensions around joint military exercises between the allies.
